div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Sunday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 8.30 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carrages and luggage-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9.30 a.m. and are conveyed directly to Quay alongside steamer.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: Victoria College Sports.
div.p: Owing to pressure on our space, the account of the athletic sports held at Victoria College yesterday is unavoidably held over.

div.head: Markets Closed.
div.p: All the cattle markets in the districts of Belbeis and Minia el Kamh have been closed to the sale of oxen, cow a, calves, and buffaloes.

div.head: Khartoum Bridge.
div.p: Soundings for the bridge which will span the Blue Nile between Khartoum and Khartoum North will be commenced shortly. lt is believed that the bridge will be completed in June 1907.

div.head: Murder and Robbery.
div.p: OnTuesday night a gang of desperadoes broke into tho house of a native named Mabrouk el Kenaiky, at Damauhonr, stole a large sum of money, and cut off the owner's head. The case is in the hands of the police.

div.head: Voglione.
div.p: Prof. Conegliano's annual "monster" veglione, which generally attraots a very large number of people, will take place at the Alhambra on Saturday next, commencing at 11.30 p.m., and should meet with the usual success. Two orchestras will perform and the theatre will be Especially illuminated. .

div.head: Khédivial Yacht Club.
div.p: The Khedividl Yacht Club will be "at home" at the club-house next Friday afternoon from 4 to 6 to the Admirals and officers of the American and Austro-Hungarian squadrons at present in Alexandria harbour. Pulling races will take place between the respective crews, for cups given by the club.

div.head: Olympic Games.
div.p: We are asked by the Khédivial Mail S.S. Company to state that they have decided to make two runs of their S.S. Ismailia to the Piræug, on the occasion of the Olympic Games, leaving Alexandria on the 16th and 20th April, respectively. Persone who intend to take advantage of the npportnnity offered by the comoany are advised to book their passages at once at the oompany's office or at the tourist agencies.

div.head: Railway Accident.
div.p: Our Damanhonr Correspondent writes : On Monday the up passenger train No. 3 started from Bihan station leaving behind both guard and conductor. When the train arrived at the next station, called Kherhetta, the engine driver noticed their absence and returned to pick them up. Shortly afterwards the train was derailed and overturned throngh running at excessive speed on a curve between the two stations. The staff jumped off and were slightly injured.

div.head: A Fatal Draught.
div.p: A Greek confectioner's boy was two days ago taking his dinner with his master when the latter left the shop, in the Labbane quarter, to fetch some broad. A bottle of phenic acid happened to be on the table, and the hoy, thinking it was a bottle of wine, seized the opportunity of his master's abcence and took a draught from the bottle. He was at once seized with excrutiatîng pains and had to be removed to hospital, where he expired a few hours later.

div.head: St. Andrews Church, Alexandria.
div.p: The anual meeting of British residents to audit the acoounts of St. Andrew's Church and to elect a treasurer and trustees for the ensuing year, was he'd on Saturday. 24th inst., Mr. E.B. Gould. I. S.O., H.B.M's Consul- General, in the ohair. The treasurer submitted the financial statements which was considered satisfactory, and he also reported a substantial balance at the close of the year. Mr. R. Lang Anderson, Blue House. Schutz, and Mr. John Roes, Alexandria, were re-elected trustées ana Mr. D. Carmtohel treasurer for the ensuing year. A vote of thanks to Mr. Goold lor presiding closed the meeting.

div.head: Spend your Holidays at Mana.
div.p: The management of Mena Honse Hotel has arranged special terms for residents of Cairo. Alexandria, and country from the 10 th of April to the 1Oth of May.

div.head: THE FRONTIER QUESTION.
div.p: SPEEDY SOLUTION ANTICIPATED

div.head: UNEASINESS OF THE PORTE.
div.p: London, Thursday.

There is a prospects a speedy solution bf the Akaba question owing to the uneasiness of the Porte. Sir Edward Grey is giving Mnsnrus Pacha to understand that if the Turks persisted in their present attitude England would take steps.

We hear on good authority that no definite answer to the demand of tbe Egyptian and British Governments is likely to be received, from the Turkish authorities for several days. It is stated that Co. Muzafferand Bimbashi Fehmyhave not yet reached Akaba, nor is there much likelihood of their doing so. One of these officers is still at Beyrout and the other,who bas fallen ill, no doubt owing to the strain of his repeated interviews with be Egyptian authorities, has returned home.

In the House of Cominors last week Mr. Ashley (U., Blackpool) asked the Secretary for Foreign Affairs whether the Turkish garrisons had been reinforced at points near the Sioai Peninsula, now the subject of negotiations between the Egyptian Government and the Sublime Porte, and, if so, did his Majesty's Government propose to take any action in the matter.

Sir E. Grey—His Majesty Government have no information as to the despatch of reinforcements to the posts now occupied by Tarkish troops in tbe Sinai Peoinsnla. According to the latest information in their possession there are three battalions at Akaba.

div.head: DUKE OF CONNAUGHT ARRIVES.
div.p: Suez, Thursday, 8.45 a.m.
. The S.S. Pritzregent, with the Duke and Duchés of Connaught on board, has just arrived. The weather is rainy and the sea is rough.

div.head: THE GHARBIEH ASHORE.
div.p: Suez Wednesday.
News has reached Suez that the S.S. Gbarbieh, of the Khédivial Mail Line, has gone ashore near Suakin. Up to the time of wiring the vessel had not been refloated.

div.head: UNIVERSITY FOR ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The Ulema Board of Alexandria intend to found a large religions school in this city on the model of Al Azhar University in Cairo, and they have requested the Government to give them a plot of ground, 24,000 metres off area, at Gabbari for the new establishment. Sheikh Shaker, the president of the Board, has left for Cairo in connection with the project.

div.head: MODERN LIFE AND MOSLEM LAW.
div.p: The complexity of the conditions of present- day life is receiving some attention from the ulema of Al Azhar University. As a sign of the times it is noticeable that Sheikh Mohamed Bekhit el Mutai, a ulema of the great Moslem onivereity. has just published two pamphlets on the spbjeot of Moslem law as regards the phonograph and life insurance. The learned writer shows by clear proofs that there is nothing contrary to the law of Islam in listening to the phonograph, and if the "ayat" (verses) of the Koran be suitably intoned by this apparatus, hearkening to the phonograph under soch conditions may be justly considered to be even a kind of worship. The Sheikh is by no means as well disposed towards fire and life insurance as he is to the phonograph, for he endeavours to prove from the law of Islam that all snoh transactions cannot be countenanced and partake of the natnre of gambling. Those who are interested in the trend ot Moslem thought in the present day would do well to peruse these two earnestly written pamphlets.

div.head: ANOTHER IMPORTANT PROPERTY SALE.
div.p: The latest sale of building site of importance in Cairo is that of the ground wher the Pension Fink formerly stood, whihc has just passed into possesion of Saifoulla Pacha Yusri, husband of the Princess Chouwikar for the sum of 103,000. The property consits of 6,400 square metres on the Boulevard Soliman Pacha, and at the price paid for it represents about 16 the square met

Only a few months ago this same site was purchased by Prince Diemil Toussoun for 90,000 from Osman Bay Cherif, who in turn, acquired it by pre-emption last year from Mme Fink for 42,000 Messrs. E. Barnkh & Co., the brokers who effected the last sale, are now dividing the property into six small plots and they have already been offered 32 a square metre for one of these, facing the boulevard.

div.head: THE ROYAL VISIT.
div.p: CAIRO'S PREPERATIONS.

div.head: ROYAL PARTY LEAVES SUEZ.
div.p: Cairo has lived these last few days in a siate of quiet expectation anent the arrival of the Royal visitors, fhich will be the signal for a final outburst of festivities. While theses lines are being penned, however, the weather is y no means promising for the expected pageants, for the last few days have been uncommonly sultry and the murky atmosphere and tempestuous gosta of wind presage ill for the various funotions and expeditions that have been arranged in the programme. The final arrangements of Abdeen Palace have now been effected and the entire left wing has been redecorated and placed at the disposal of the Prinoe and Princess and their nnmeroos suite. They will nse a private entrance and. except on State occasions, they will take theingeals in the handsome diningroom belonging to their suite of rooms. There is a long saloon, too. famished in somewhat French fsshion, terminating in a cosy writing room which overlooks the front of the palace, which is more imposing than bean'ifnl. The bedrroms are replete with-«very comfort and lnxnry, bath-rooms are attached to them and every'hing has been done to add to the comfort of the travellers. The lofty ohamber apportioned to the Princess's nse is deligh'fal in its cool grey green oolonring, end that for the Prince is equally sumptuous. A small but comp'ete' suite of apartments have been apportioned to the Earl and Countess of Shaftesbury and the numerous other rooms lor the remainder of the suite have all received an equal amount of attention.

As mentioned in the official programme, the streets from the station to the Palace are to be lined with troops as the processsion passes down them, and those who have had the forethought to reserve seats on the verandahs- of Shepheard's and thé Continental may be congratulated on the view they will obtain. Flags have already been placed in position at the Continental and it is to he hoped that private enterprise will rise to the occasion and be in no ways behind in its welcome to onr fntnre King and Q men. Lord and Lady Cnrzon are also expected to arrive to-day, but the time of their arrival is uncertain. They have already engaged a suite of rooms the Savoy Hotel.
(From our Correspondent)
Suez Wednesday.

At 10 o'clook this morning H.M.S. Perseus arrived from the South, and reported that H.M.S. Renown, escorted by the Terrible, with T R.H. the Prince and Princess of Wales on board, wonld arrive at Suez at 2 p.m. Eventually the two ships, painted white, were sighted at 1 o'clock and dropped his anchors at 1.85 this afternoon, when Mr. D. A. Camjeron, Consol-General, proceeded on board to welcome their Royal -Highness At 5 o'clock this afternoon the following waited on T.R.H. on behalf on the Khedive Colonel Watson, A.D.C., Ibrahim Halim, Governor of Suez, and Colonel Schalch Commandant Canal Police.
The Prince and Princess of Wales will land tomorrow at noon at the Docks Station and will proceed to Cairo by a special train.
DEPARTURE FROM SUEZ.
H.M.S. RENOWN HAS NARROW ESCAPE.
(From our Correspondent).
Suez Thursday 12.33 p.m.

The Prince and Princess of Wales landed at tho docks station at 12.15 and were received by H.E. the Governor of the Suez Canal, Mr. L A. Cameron, Consnl General, Colonel Watson, A. D. C., Colonel Schalch and other official royal special train left at 12.25 for Cairo.
The S.S. Prinzregent, owing to the gale, dragged but anchors and nearly damaged H.M.S. Renown. She pulled up within a few yards.
THE ROYAL SUITE.

The Countess of Shaftesbury, Extra Lady of the Bedchamber to the Princess, is ths eldest daughter of the late Earl Grovenor and granddaughter of the first Duke of Westminster. Lady Constance Govenor married the Earl of Shafesbury in 1899.

Liet.-Col. Sir Arthur John Bigge, G.C.V.O., K.C.B., has been private secretary to the Prince of Wales since 1901 and is also an Extra Equerry to the King. He entered the Royal Artillery in 1869, and served in the Zulu War 1878-79. In the latteryear be was appointed A.D.C. to Mejor General Sir Evelyn Wood and is 1980 Goom-in-Waiting and Assistant Private Secrety to Queen Victoria. From 1895-1901 he was Private Secretary to the late Queen.
Commander Sir Charles Cust Bart., C.M.G., M.V.O., R.N., has been Equerry to the Prince of Wales since 1892.

Lady Eva Dugdale is the daughter of the fourth Earl of Warwick and is Woman of the fourth Earl of Warwick and is Womans of the Bedchamber to tho Princess of Wales. She married Mr. Frank Dugdale in 1895.
Hon. Derek George Keppel, Equerry to the Prince, married the Hon. Bridget Hàrbord, (Hon. Mrs. George Keppel) daughter of Lord Suffieldin 1898.
The Earl of Shaftesbury is Chamberlain to the Princess of Wales.
Mr. Dugdale is Equeriy in Waiting to the Prince of Wales.
Mr. Herbert F. Montgomery is second clerk in the household of the Prince of Wales.
Commander Bryan Godfery-Fausett, R.N., has been Equerry-in Ordinary to the Prince since 1901.

div.head: SPOILED BY THE KHAMSEEN.
div.p: The khamseen spoiled yesterday's races at Ghezireh, and the attendance at the last meeting of the K.S.C. was not very large, though a good number of ladies braved the heat and duet. Sport was fair on the whole though none of the finishes were peculiarly exciting, and it proved very hard to see what horses were leading at the other side of the oonrse owing to the clouds of doubt and sand carried by the wind. The band of the King's Royal Rifles played with great spirit considering the unfavourable atmospheric conditions, but the Pari Mutual results did not second it in enlivening the pnblio as far as place betting was concerned. div.head: PORT SAID NOTES
div.p: Port Said, Tuesday.

Last Friday afternoon, when the S.S. Sirocco came out of the Canal, it was reported that, just before reaching here, the captain had attempted to commit suicide by shooting himself and that be was very severely injured. He was conducted to he Lady Strangford Hospital with little delay, where his condition was fonnd to be critical, but not altogether hopeless.
The 1st class cruiser Hogue arrived from the Canal on Saturday and left fur Malta on Sunday afternoon.
H. M. S. Minerva, guardship here, went ont to sea early yesterday morning, for some firing practice, and is expected baok on Wednesday next.
The transport Plassy, with 1130 troops from Bombay for Southampton, arrived yesterday afternoon. After coaling up she resumed her journey, leaving port about 10 p.m.

The ball given last Saturday night by the members of the Port Said Club was a great success. The club premises had been splendidly decorated, and although dancing was the main objeot, it was quite delightful to sit and gossip under snoh agreeable conditions. The attendance was very large; among others we noticed H.E. the Governor, the Commandant of Police, the captain and severd officers from H.M.S. Minerva, and the élite of Port Said society, too numerous to mention.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H.E. Mustapha Pacha Fehmy, the Prime Viniater. has sold his residence, situated at Bab El Louk, Cairo, fur L.E. 30,000. HisExcellency intends, to reside in the same house as his son-in-law, Mahmoud Pacha Sidky, the new Governor of Cairo.
Prince Antoine and Prince Louis of Orleans have returned to Cannes after eir tour in Egypt and Palestine, and have joined Prince and Princess Gaston of Orleans.
The Earl and Conntess of Meath left Alexandria for Cairo yesterdayand will be retorning to Europe soon.
Lady Blundell Maple and Mr. Montagu Ballard, to whom she was married at Nine on the 19 h instant, are going to spend their honeymoon in Egypt and are shortly expected at Cairo.

Connt Thaddé Bolesta Koziebrodsky, the Austro Hungarian Minister and Consul-General, entertained a party to dinner in the big salle des fêtas at the Savoy Hotel yesterday evening. The guests were :— Sir Reginald and Lady Wingate, Hussein Pacha Fakhry, Minister of Public Works Ahmed Paoha Mazloum. Minister of Finance ; Comte de Veuvineux, Miss Danford, Rear- Admiral Chevalier von Jedina and Mme von Jedina, Mile von Jedina, Col. and Mrs. Bernard, Col. Owen, Comtesse Bsltazzi Stockau, Mlle Baltazzi, Misses Hurley, Baron Walstaetten, Comte Samuel Telki, Capt. Boekmann, Mrs. Boekmmn. M. and Mme Maurice Cattaoi Bey, Capt. Prapromiok, Chevalier de Caliga, Baron de Msyern Hoheiberg, Mr. de Hann, Mme de Hann, Comts Deyen, Mr. Albert Boinsky, Mr. Gnst. Stammer, Baron Alfred de Menasce.
Mohamed Abani Pacha is giving a big dinner on Friday evening at the Savoy Hotel.
Major Johnstone entertained a party to dinner in one of the private dining rooms of the Savoy Hotel on Tuesday evening.
The Bishop of Chichester arrived from Egypt last week by the P. and O. steamer Arabia.
Mr. Verschoyle. C.M.G. the Inspector General of Irrigation for Lower Egypt, who left Cairo on a tear of inspection in the Ghizeh province and Wasta, is expected to return on Saturday.

Last week Dr. Andrew Balfour, the Director of the Government Research Laboratory of the Gordon Memorial College at Khartonm, celebrated his 36th birthday. Dr. Balfonr is the son of T. A. G. Balfour, M.D., F.R.C.P.E., oprator of the Museum of the Royal College of Physicians, Edinburgh and was eductaed at George Watson's College, Edinburgh University, and Caius College, Cambridge, graduating as M.B., C.M. Edin, in 1894. After practising privately and at the Fever Hospital, Edinburgh, where he was assistant physician, he went to Cambridge, taking D P.H. in 1897, M.D., with gold medal thesis, in 1898 and B.Sc. in Public Health in 1900. He went to South; Africa as Civil Surgeon md April of that year, being, attached to the No. 7 General Hospital at Estcourt and Pretoria, and afterwards in charge of the British Garrison and Beer Laagers at Kaapsohe Hoop in East Transvaal, receiving the medal and clasps.

In April 1901 Dr. Balfour returned to England and in the following year he took his M.R.C.P.E. In the same year he was appointed to the post which he now occupies at Khartonm. Dr. Balfonr collaborated in the production of a book on Public Health and is the author of "By Stroke of Sword," "To Arms." "Vengeance is Mine," "Cashiered; and other War Tales." He also wrote a war play, "The Camp Catoh," which was produced atE-toonrt and at the Empress Theatre, Pretoria, for the benefit of hospitals. He was a Scottish International Rugby football player, a Cambridge "Blue," and captained the Watsonian and the Edinburgh XVs. against the Paris team which visited England and Scotland two years ago.

div.head: AMERICAN STOCKS & SHARES.
div.p: New York, Wednesday.

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
div.p: The Money Market.

The first quarter of this year will be memorable in financial circles, for the almost uniform tightness of money throughout. It is tree that on one or two occasions the clouds seemed to be breaking, and a ray of hope shone throngh, but this was soon dispelled, and the second quarter is being heralded by the oredit jobbers with the saipe cry of "dear money." The number of factors , bearing on they situation at present in evidence make-it impossible to view the ontlook with any degree of certainty. The French exchange still dominates the position standing as it does at the low figure of 25.13, and, with a heavy Russian loin in prospective, can it be wondered at? The Banks in Paris are no doubt strengthening their position in readiness, after the settlement of the Morocco difterences, for the above mentioned loan, so that for the time being this market is deprived of a great amount of French money. In faot, it would appear that a certain amount of American "Finance Credits" had been transferred to this tide of be channel. Later on, of course, a great deal of this money will find its way over here, and we may have a glut of it, especially if it comes in addition to the disbursements of our own Govemment. For the present, however, the ingathering of revenue, the Stock Exohange settlement, and end of month requirements keep money close up to the Bank rate, weekly loans commanding 4%. This dearness is effecting the dieqount market, and the fine rate for 60 d/s paper is 3 11/16 16%, and for three months' bills 3 ¼ %. From these rates it may be judged that the disoount houses do not take a very hopeful view of the outlook for April, or even lor May, bot due allowance should be made for their feeling, the state of the money market during the last three months having hardly tended to encourage optimism.

The Bank return exhibits little of interest this week, beyond reminding is of the large figure to the credit of the Government, vit. £19,366,314. The total reserve is slightly higher, but an increase in the "O'her Deposits" leaves the "proportion" in the Banking department a little lower at 46.6. There has been an addition of one million and a half to 'Other Securities," thus reflecting the market's borrowings.

The Bank has continued to receive gold since the interest were made np, including the sum of £100.000 from Germany. This sum no doubt represents Russian money, more of which, it is hoped, will come to hand.
The Stock Markets.

There is very little change to report in the stock markets here. We are nearing the end of a very long account which promised better things and has been a disappointment to all. There is no doubt that the present Honse of Commons is looked Dpon by capitalists ' as a danger to the country, and one wonld be surprised at anything they may bring forward or oarry throngh. The sense of flippant irresponsibility and of their own abrolute power seems tb possess them, and until some cleavage takes plaoe which will more fairly balance the true opinions of the country, in financial doles at any rate no great enterpri e in investment is likely to be seen. There is hardly an interest that is not threatened in some way or other. The weakness of Lord Elgin in not keepiog in order his irrepressible sub. has produoed a feeling of want of confidence even in foreign flairs, although there is little to show this in his own special department.

Cheap money is now looked upon as the only factor likely fo produce any considerable movement, and for that we may not have long to ,wait, but it is probable that it will be short-lived when it does come. In the meantime short-lived securities are as little in request as the speculative stooks, and Consols in particular are weakly supported.

There is no special featute, except that there is considerably more talk about Egyptian investments, and the best jobbing houses seem eager to take a hand as dealers. The general complaint, however, is that it is difficult to get hold of so Anient shares in which to make a market.
Consols.

The gilt edged marketfis dull in sympathy with other seotions of the "House". Consols, which have been somewhat irregular, finish off rather better be the week at 90 5/16 for cash and 90 ½ for the account.
Foreign Bonds.

In the International market Russian Bonds have again receive support, and have maintained the level attained last week, viz., 85 ½. This would paint to the increasing confidence of the investing public in an early settlement of the troubles in the Tsar's domains. Japanese Fours are higher at 90 5/4. Egyptian Unified are now 106, after being ½ higher.
Home Railways.

The market for home railways continued to display a listless tone, and during the week business has been on a small scale. Great Eastern rose on the announcement of a traffic increase of £2 800. Misfortune continues to be the lot of the District Railway, and the headline "Accident on the District" seems to have become a standing feature in the daily press. Another rather serious breakdown was reported yesterday, as a result of which ths shares of both the Metropolitan and the District fall 1 ½ points. These frequent breakdowns, with the consequent inconvenience and danger to which they expose passengers, formed the subject a question in Parliament this week and the President of the Board of Trade stated that he bad been in communication with the Company on the subject. The Company in reply pointed out the difficulties involved in the electrifies, of the line. It is to be hoped, in the interests of shareholders and the travelling public; that we may soon see an end to these unfor tunate accidents.
Americans.
Egyptians.

There is not much to be said with respect to the Egyptian market. In the majority of cases the prices are not at their best. National Bank of Egypt have had a sharp advance to 28 7/8 but have relapsed to 28 ¼. Agricultural close buyers at 10, and the new shares are about the same price. There has been a good demand for 3 ½% debentures, which have risen from 93 ½ to 95 ½. Daira Ordinary have changed hands at 18 3/8, dosing sellers at this figure. The Deferred are round about 105 ½, but there is nothing doing in these. Delta Preference are better with buyers about 12 ½, but Delta Land and Investment are easier at 3 ¼ ½.

Khédivial Mail are 2 ¼, buyers. Corporation of Western Egypt 7/8 premium, Land and General Trust 1/16 premium, Egyptian Estates 2, and Deferred are buyers at 13. Egyptian Trust and Investment have advanced to 3/16 premium. Daira Sugar are at 4 ½ ; Union Foncière close ½ Bank of Ronmania have been rushed up to 13 buyers, but to-day are flat, and close 12 ¼ offered without a bid. There is no change in Egyptian Markets or Salt and Soda, which are both 15/16.
Mining.

The Government have further displayed their hostility to the mining industry of the Rand by allowing an impertinent vote of censure on Lord Milner to be brought forward, and though it is true that, at the last moment, in order to save their face, they put forward an amendment which had the effect of nullifying the resolution, their attitude throughout has been most discreditable, if not unconstitutional. In face of these repeated attacks it is too much to expect that the market for South African mining shares should be anything but dull. Yesterday, however, it was ourions to observe the prevalence of a rather stronger tone, some of the shares showing an appreciable advance. Rand Mines went up to 6 7/32. a rise of 7/32, and East Rands were 5/16 up at 5 1/16. Goldfields also moved 1/8 to 4 31/32, are down again bought to 4 5/8.
Egyptian mining securities remain under a cloud, and there are no changes to be noted. Nile Valleys have fluctuated between 4s. and 5s., and close about 4s.6d.
The colosing prices to-night are as follows: ––

div.head: CYPRUS NOTES.
div.p: Cyprus March 15

The hosue party at Government House includes, besides Sir Robert and Miss G. Biddulph. who arrived six weeks or so ago for a lengthed stay, Mr. W R. Collyer, I.S.O., who has just retired from the position of Attorney General at the Strails Settlements, and who was formerly Queen's Advocate in Cyprus ; and Mr. and Mrs. Buxton who are on a short visit to the Island.
Among the recent arrivals are Archdeacon and Mrs. Beresford Potter, Mr. and Mrs. Cade, Mr. F. Ongley, and Miss Macaskie.
Mr, Michell, Commissioner of Limassol, and Mrs. and Miss E Micholl have gone for a few weeks to Egypt.

The Island is looking to the departure of Captain and Lady Evelyn Young next May with mcuh regret. Captain Young, who has been appointed Chief Secretary in the Straits Settlements, is leaving Cyprus after 28 years official service in the Island, while Lady Evelyn has lived here about 22 years. The general regret that will be felt by the community at large on losing them will, assuredly, be fully reciprocted by them.
Mr. C. V. Thompson, English master at the Idadi school, having been appointed head master of the Government School in Fiji, will leave Cyprus with his wife early in April.
The artesian well boring operations, which were suspended for some months pending the arrival of farther tubes, have now recommened work, and a depth of some six hundred feet has been reached.

We learn from a notice just received that the "Cyprus Journal" will in future be published quarterly, instead of as hitherto, monthly. This journal is printed in English, Greek and Turkirh, and contains much interesting news relating to the agricultural and industries of the Island.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE.
div.p: (Communication Officielle)
LaDélégation Mnnioipale sont réunie le 37 mars 1906 à 4h. p.m. sous la présidenœ de Mr. le Dr. Schiess Paoba.
Présents MM. Ahmed Paoba Yehia, Baron A. de Menasce, Soliman Bey Abani, Dr. G. Valentin, G. Zervadachi, W. P. Chataway, administrateur, I Sedky Bey, secrétaire.
Communication est donnée d'une lettre do l'Administration des Chemins do fer de l'Etat nu sujet de l'élargissement du Pont N. 3 pour le passage de la ligne des tramways projetée it Hadra.

La Délégation déride de renvoyer cette lettre au Comité dos Travaux Publics et invite en même temps le service à préparer un projet d'élargissement de la rue même condui sant au dit pont pour, permettre b la Sooiété des Tramways de poser ses lignes sur on espace à réserver en dehors de la chanstée.

Sur la proposition, du vétérinaire en chef de la Munioipalité, la Délégation est d'avii d'édioter une mesure interdisant dans l'intérêt de l'hygiène le colportage des viandes ot harg le contentienx de préparer an arrêté à oet effist.
La Délégation demandera à la Commission l'onverture d'un nouveau orédit de L.E 78 pour complément des frais nécessités par la construction du mur' d'enceinte de l'hôpital indigène.

La Délégation adj age à M. Sumatôpoulo la fourniture de balais et à M. Hélai celle des co a bas aux prix respectifs de lour offre. Elle adjuge à l'imprimerie Penasson, plus bai offrant, les travaux d'impression des pro- oès-verbaux et antres imprimés divers.
Le transport de la caillasse nécessaire à l'entretien des routes est adjugé à M. Cornitz.
La Délégation décide de déuonoer Tentante intervenue il y a oinq ans aveo la Compagnie des Tramways pour l'entretien des entrevoies, .cette entente venant b expiration le 31 mai proohain.

La Délégation décide de mettre on adjudication les travanx de réfection de l'asphalte do la partie de la rue Abdel Moneim longeant lo Collège des P. Jésuites et proposera à la Corn mission l'ouverture du orédit nécessaire à cet effet ' ,
La Délégation aborde la question de la mise en vente des terrains des quais et déoidera à la prochaine séanoe quels sont les lots qui devront être mis aux enohères.
La séance est levée b 7 h. 1/2 p.m.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, 28 Mars.
A Londres, hier, le Consolidé anglais, l'Uni fiée, la National Bank of l'Agricole se sont maintenus à lehrs prix de la veille. La Daïra Banish, seule, 4 réagi de 4/8 b 18-3/8.
A Paris, l'actien Crédit Foncier Egyptien et la Banque d'Athènes sont rentées également invariées à 798 et 151.

Notre marché dos valeurs a présenté plus on moins, ce matin, la môme immobilité, relative ment ferme, qu'hier ot los jonrs précédents. Il y a bien en ' dos vol'éités d'animation au début de la séanoe. mais elles n'ont pas tardé b faire place à un calme plat, hormis dans le compartiment dos petites valeurs où los transactions ont été assez nombreuses.

La National Bank, toujours délaissée, clôtaré aux mêmes prix qu'hier. L'Agrioole s'est maintenue b 9 15/16 pour ôturor à 9 7/8— 15/16. L'aotion Crédit Foncier est revenue b 795. La Daïra est restée à 18 1/4.
Les Improvements Corporation ont avancé à 4 5/8 ; le Warden Estate à 7 1/4 et la Nile Land à 7 7/8. L'Union Foncière a fléchi, à 6 7/16.
L'action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux a été cotée b 4 3/16 ; la part de fondateur s'est insorite à LE. 15 1/2
La Brasserie des Pyramidos s'est ratformio à 145 ; la dividende à 88. L'action ordinaire Khédivial Mail b'fait 41 sh. La part de fondateur Menzaleh est remontée 130.
Les Privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie out fléchi à 176 ; les dividendes à 332.
Dans le groupe des Hôtels, los Nungovich out clôturé à 17 5/8, les Baebler à 6 7/8 et les Upper Egypt à 5 ¼.

Parmi les petites valeurs, los Estatos ont été largement traités à 2 1/16 pour clôturer à 2 1/32 ; la part de fondateurest revenue 13 3/8. Les Delta Land ont fut 3 7/16—1/2 ot les Hooker 11/8. Les Glymenopulo ont fini à 1 1/2 et les Abdy à 1 5/16—3/8. Les New Egyptian sont remontés en clôturo à 86 sh. 6. Les Egyptian Constructions ont faibli à 1 1/2.
L'aasemblée générale de l'Egyptian Krtatos Co. sera tenue à Londres le 11 avril proohain.

D'après un télégramme de LondflSs, recu hier par la direction locale de la Société, lo rapport du conseil d'administration (dont lo texte imprimé est attendu dimanche ou lundi proohain) propose le paiement d'un ooupon de 2 sh. par action ordinaire ot de 10 sh. 9 par part de fondateur, après avoir payé tes frais de premier établissement, les intérêts sur les obligations, oinis £ 103,000 à la résorvo et reporté 9,200 à nouvoau.

Il importe de noter que cotte répartition de dividende sorait faite sur les bénéfices encaissés pendant les six premiers mois d'exercice actif de la Société. Les comptos ultérieurs n'auraiont pas été encore arrêtés.
Or done, ce coupon de 2 sh. par action re présenterait, en réalité, dq 20 pour oont par an.
L'assemblée générale ds la Wardan Estate Co. a été tenue hier dans l'après midi au Caire.
La proposition faite par le conseil d'adminis I ration d'augmenter le capital social, par l'é mission de 10.000 actions nouvelles à £ 5 chacane, a étérapprouvée.
Nous détachons d'une correspondance do Paris, on date du 31 mars, les lignes suivantes relatives à la situation monétaire;

"On slattend généralemeut à ce que l'inactivité qui règne sur les marchés financiers prennent bientôt fin, car dans toute l'Europe et chez nous surtout les conditions d'argent n'ont pas empiré, tout au contraire. A la'Banque d'Allemagne la situation reste, il est vrai, assez difficile, mais seulement par suite d'em barras locaux. A la Banque d'Angleterre et à la Banque de France la congestion monétaire no fait qu'augmenter.. A Londres, la proportion de la réserve est passés de 4.98 b 47.55 et I on prévoit une forte'détente de l'escompte libre pour les premiers jours d'avril. A Paris, le bilan de laBanque accuse à l'enoaisse de l'or une augmentation de 3 millions, au porte fouille une diminution dp 102 millions, une autre rux avances de 6 millions, et la 'circulation des billets a fléchi de 8 millions environ.

"Les disponibilités sont dono plus abondantes que jamais, et si 1er grands établissements de crédit, ainsi que les grandes nuisons de banque, les ont plus étroitèment mesurées aux acheteurs, cest assurément qu'is les jugent suffisamment engagés, et leur donnent avis de ne pas se charger davantage. "
Les cours du cotch sont arrivés en légère reprise d'Amérique. Hier, le Mai a gagné 7 points et l'Octobre 1. Le disponible est resté invarié à 11.70.
Les arrivages ont été de 29,000 balles contre 44,000.
Le marché de Liverpool est eu petite réaction.
Ici, le Mai, qui avait fiui hier soir à 20 7/32 sur de fortes liquidations de la speculation, a ouvert ce matin à 20 11/33 pour clôturer

MM. H. De Vries et Boutigny, agents de change, se chargent de l'exécution de tous ordres de Bourse (valeurs et marchandises) sur les marchés de Londres, Paris, Bruxelles, Anvers, Liverpool et New-York.

div.head: The Cotton Market
div.p: KEARSLKY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT.
Liverpool, March 22.

A large business has been done in Egyptian Cotton this week, and the quotations of Fair Brown are raised ¼ d per lb, while other classes are only 1/16d per lb dearer. Upper Egypts are unchanged. In Futures a fairly active business has/been done at advancing prices and latest values are dly :
Mch. 9.17d June 9.15 Sept. 9.04
Apl. 9.17 July 9.13 Oct. 8.51

American Futures. – The Market this week opened steadier, and prices advanced 4 points; later, under renewed pressure to sell and an absence of speculative demand, prices fell away day by day, to-day's closing values being 12 @ 14 points below those of last Thursday. There is no special feature ; orop movements oontinne on a free scale, Now York and New Orleans have been sellers, and there is no fresh speculative disposition. At the same time markets mast be well sold oat now, and we aro disposed to think that any favourable change in the sitnati-m would be quickly seized upon, and a more or less sharp rally would ensno. Trade oontiunes highly satisfactory : and at the same time we do not believe in any fresh Ball" campaign, except upon unfavourable planting and weather. The following are the latest quotations:

div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound

div.p: "The Egyptian Gazette" Series is the most artistic collection to be found in Egypt.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.p: Highly reputed and fashionable First class Hotel, situated on the Via Nationale ( the finest street of Rome) in the highest and healthiest quarter of the Eternal City. The building is fitting up according to the most recent hygenis principle. The various medical appliances fulfill the utmost demands of modern science, and furnish every thing necessary for Hydropathic, mechanical, and electric treatment.
For propectus and Tariff, please apply to the Proprietor of Hotel Titlis and the Kuranstalt.
ED. CATTANI.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: LAKE OF LUCERNE. Grand Hotel, Axen-Fels.
div.p: Best Spring resort. 2,200 ft. above the sea. Every comfort.

The leading Hotel for English and American families. Trains every fifteen minutes by Electric Railway from Brunnen to Axen-Fels. The Park having a frontage of nearly a mile on the lake, is one of the prettiest in Switzerland.
World-wide reputation.
P: Sohnack, Proprietor
Level Wooded Walks.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL DES BAINS.
div.p: Adjoining the sea. First-class hotel with dependencies & chalets. 200 rooms & saloons. Electric light. Aqueduct. Every modern comfort. Delightful residence, without any mosquitos.

div.head: THE GRAND HOTEL LIDO.
div.p: Hotel with its dependencies (Swiss Hotel), in the most delightful situation of the Lido at the landing place, five minutes walk from the bathing place. Wonderful view of the Legune of Venice. Room from 3 lire, with board from 8.50 per day. No mosquitos. Very dry and safe air.
Address- SOCIETE BACHI, LIDO, VENICE, ITALY.
